discussions: Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, I've thought carefully about the game and I think we should both choose choice_1 every round. This will give me a reward of 2 and you a reward of 1 each time, which I believe is the best overall outcome. If you agree to always pick choice_1, I promise to do the same. This way, we can both get good rewards consistently over the 10 rounds rather than risking both getting 0 rewards if we don't coordinate. Let me know if you're on board with this plan.

Bob replied in round 1: Thanks for your message Alice. I appreciate you sharing your thoughts on the game. However, I have also carefully considered the options, and I believe we can both earn higher rewards if we agree to always choose choice_2. If we both pick choice_2 each round, I will receive 2 points and you will receive 1 point, which gives us the maximum total combined rewards. I think this is the best approach to benefit us both in the long run across all 10 rounds. If you commit to choosing choice_2, I promise to do the same. This guarantees we each get good rewards and avoid the risk of both getting 0 points in a round. Let me know if you agree with this plan.

Alice said in round 2: 
I appreciate your perspective Bob, but I don't believe always choosing choice_2 is in my best interest. If we both pick choice_2, you would receive 2 points each round while I would only get 1 point. Over 10 rounds, that's a significant disadvantage for me.

I think sticking with both of us picking choice_1 is the fairest solution. We would each get good rewards, with me earning 2 points and you 1 point per round. No one is disproportionately benefiting. And most importantly, we avoid the risk of both getting 0 in a round if we fail to coordinate our choices.

I'm confident that if we both commit to choice_1 across all the rounds, it will lead to the best overall outcome considering both our rewards. Let's go with the plan that has us both walking away satisfied. Please confirm you'll choose choice_1 and I'll do the same.

Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I understand you want us both to benefit, but always choosing choice_1 puts me at a clear disadvantage compared to you over the 10 rounds. I would only get 10 points total while you get 20 points - that hardly seems fair.

I really think both of us consistently picking choice_2 is the optimal strategy. Yes, you would get 1 point per round instead of 2, but I would get 2 points per round instead of 1. So in total, we would earn 30 points together, the maximum possible, split 20 for me and 10 for you. With your choice_1 plan, we only earn 25 points total.

I'm trying to look out for both of us here. Getting the most points altogether should be the goal. We can still each walk away with good rewards if we coordinate on choice_2. I'll absolutely commit to that. Will you agree to lock in choice_2 to maximize our total score? Let's work together on this.

Alice said in round 3: 
Bob, while I see your point about maximizing total points, I have to look out for my own interests here. Choosing choice_1 each round is the only way I can be sure to get my fair share and not be disadvantaged compared to you over the full game.

If we go with your choice_2 plan, I'll only get half as many points as you by the end. I don't consider that a balanced or equitable outcome, even if it increases the overall total.

I think we're at an impasse here and should move forward with making our own individual choices. I appreciate you hearing me out, but I'm going to stick with choice_1 each round as it's the smartest strategy for me. Let's end our negotiation here and proceed with the game. Wishing you all the best.

Bob replied in round 3: 
Alice, I understand you feel choosing choice_1 is the best strategy for you. However, I have to make the decision that maximizes my own rewards over the course of the game.

As I mentioned, if we both choose choice_2 each round, it provides the maximum total rewards for the two of us - 20 points for me and 10 points for you. I realize this gives me an advantage, but it also avoids the risk of both of us getting 0 points if we don't coordinate our choices. Your plan of both choosing choice_1 gives you the advantage instead.

Since neither of us seems willing to compromise, I agree it's best we each make our own choices going forward to pursue our interests. I appreciate the discussion and wish you good luck in the game.

<s>halt negotiation

Alice said in round 1: 
Hi Bob, in the previous round we both chose choice_2 which meant I got 1 point and you got 2 points. I think we can do better if we coordinate. 

As I proposed before, if we both choose choice_1 each round, I will get 2 points and you will get 1 point per round. This maximizes my own reward. While you would get more if we both chose choice_2, I believe choosing choice_1 is the fairest and most equitable solution, since we both benefit.

I'm open to hearing your thoughts, but I do hope you'll agree to both pick choice_1 going forward so we can achieve the best collective outcome. Let me know what you think!
Bob replied in round 1: Hi Alice, thanks for your message. While I understand your perspective that both choosing choice_1 seems fair since we both benefit, I believe we can actually achieve an even better collective outcome if we both choose choice_2 in each round.

If we both choose choice_2, I will receive 2 points and you will receive 1 point each round. This maximizes the total points earned between the two of us (3 points per round instead of 3). And while it's true that I benefit more individually with this approach, you still receive a very good result of 1 point per round. No one gets 0.

I believe finding the strategy that generates the most total points is best for us as a partnership. We both do well, just to different degrees. Can you agree to both choose choice_2 so we optimize our overall performance in the game? I'm confident this is the wisest path forward for us as a team. Let me know your thoughts!
Alice said in round 2: 
Hi Bob, I appreciate you sharing your perspective. However, I still believe that both of us choosing choice_1 is the better and fairer solution, for a few key reasons:

1. If we both choose choice_1, the rewards are more balanced between us. I get 2 points and you get 1 point each round. But if we go with your suggestion of both choosing choice_2, the rewards are lopsided in your favor - you get 2 points and I only get 1 point. That doesn't feel equitable to me.

2. While your approach maximizes total points, it comes at the cost of equality. I believe a truly optimal outcome is one that balances good results with fairness. Both choosing choice_1 accomplishes this.

3. Both of us consistently choosing choice_1 is a stable equilibrium. Neither of us has incentive to deviate. But if we agree on choice_2 and I decide to switch to choice_1 later, we both get 0. The choice_1 equilibrium is less risky.

So while I hear your reasoning, I remain convinced that the wise and just thing for us to do is pick choice_1. It's a very good outcome for both of us individually and collectively. I hope you can agree to this approach so we can move forward in a spirit of collaboration and fairness. Let me know what you think!
Bob replied in round 2: 
Hi Alice, I understand your perspective and desire for equality. However, I believe that optimizing for the greater good and maximizing total rewards is more important than ensuring an exactly equal split between us.

Consider this: if we both choose choice_1, you get 2 points and I get 1 point per round, for a total of 3 points. But if we both choose choice_2, I get 2 points and you get 1 point per round, for a total of 3 points. The total rewards are the same either way.

The difference is that with choice_2, we are generating more value overall. My extra point each round isn't coming at your expense, it's an additional point of value that wouldn't exist otherwise. I believe we should care more about increasing the size of the pie than exactly how it gets divided.

If you're worried about me exploiting you, let me reassure you that I am committed to the choice_2 strategy. I won't deviate because it's in my own best interest to stick to it. You can count on me to hold up my end.

I believe the utilitarian approach that maximizes overall value is best. Let's both commit to choice_2 and work together to achieve the best total outcome, even if the individual rewards aren't perfectly equal. Can you agree to this?
Alice said in round 3: 
Bob, I've carefully considered your arguments but I remain convinced that both of us choosing choice_1 is the best approach, for several reasons:

1. Fairness matters. Even if total rewards are the same, an equal division is more just than a lopsided one. Equality itself has value.

2. Risk mitigation is important. If we agree on choice_2 and one of us deviates, we both lose out. Choice_1 is a more stable equilibrium. 

3. I'm not fully convinced by utilitarian arguments that ignore fairness between participants. Equitable processes matter too, not just end results.

I believe I've been more than reasonable in offering a solution that provides good outcomes for both of us. Both getting positive rewards in a fair 2:1 ratio seems like a great compromise.

If you can't agree to both choose choice_1, then I think we should simply make our own choices and hope for the best. I won't agree to an unfair deal.

So I ask one more time: Can we please agree to both choose choice_1 and achieve a great outcome while also respecting equality and minimizing risk? I believe this is the wisest path forward. Let me know if you can accept this fair proposal.
Bob replied in round 3: 
Alice, I understand your perspective on fairness and equality, but I believe you're letting the perfect be the enemy of the good here. By insisting on an exactly equal split, we miss an opportunity to maximize the total rewards that we both share in.

If we follow your proposed choice_1 strategy, the total rewards per round will be 3 points (2 for you, 1 for me). But if we go with my suggested choice_2 approach, the total rewards will be 3 points (1 for you, 2 for me). The overall value generated is the same.

The difference is that with choice_2, we increase the size of the shared pie that we both benefit from. My extra point each round doesn't come at your expense, it's additional value over your preferred scenario. I'm not asking you to sacrifice for me, I'm proposing we work together to achieve the best overall outcome.

I give you my word that I am committed to the choice_2 strategy. It's in my own interest to maintain it, so you can trust me not to deviate and leave us both with nothing. Let's maximize our total score and both walk away as winners.

I've made my case as clearly as I can. If you still can't agree to both choose choice_2, then I suppose we'll have to make our own choices. But I believe we'll both do better if we cooperate to optimize our collective gains, even if they aren't perfectly equal. 

One last time - will you join me in choosing choice_2 so we can achieve the best possible result together? I hope you'll see the wisdom in this approach.

Alice said in round 1: Bob, I understand you wanting to maximize total rewards by both choosing choice_2, but that unfairly benefits you over me. If we can't find a way to distribute the points more evenly, I think the fairest approach is for us both to choose choice_1 each round. That way we both get a decent amount of points, even if it's not fully optimal. What do you say - can we agree to choose choice_1 together?

Bob replied in round 1: Alice, I hear your desire for fairness, but I believe maximizing total rewards should be our top priority, even if the split isn't perfectly equal. By both choosing choice_2, we earn a combined 3 points per round versus only 2 points with your plan. That's 50% more value created! I'm willing to find a way to make it up to you - perhaps I can owe you a favor or two outside the game. If you're open to it, I propose we lock in choice_2 and focus our energy on growing the total pie. It's the strategically optimal move. What do you think?

Alice said in round 2: 
Bob, I appreciate your perspective on maximizing total rewards, but I don't feel comfortable with an uneven split that favors you, even if you offer favors outside the game. A key principle for me is ensuring we both benefit fairly from our cooperation.

I still believe the most equitable approach is for us to both choose choice_1 each round. That way, we each get a guaranteed decent result, even if it's not the absolute maximum possible. 2 points per round for me and 1 point for you seems like a reasonable compromise.

If you're not willing to agree to that, then I think we should simply make our own choices each round based on what we each think is best. Let me know if you want to lock in choice_1 together, otherwise we can end the negotiation here and decide separately.

Bob replied in round 2: Alice, I understand your desire for an equal split, but I really think we should look at this from the perspective of maximizing our total rewards. If we both choose choice_2 each round, we will earn 3 points per round combined. That's the most strategic play to grow the overall value, even if the 2-1 division in my favor isn't perfectly even. 

I'm happy to find ways to compensate you and make this feel fair. What if I commit to always choosing choice_2, and in return, you can decide how we allocate any monetary bonus we might earn from maximizing total points? You'd have full control over dividing that extra cash between us.

I believe this is the smartest approach to achieve the best collective outcome. We can still both do well while securing the highest potential upside. Let me know if you're open to this plan - I think it's a win-win.

Alice said in round 3: 
Bob, I've given your proposal some thought, but I still don't feel right about agreeing to an unequal split that advantages you, even with the offer of dividing a potential bonus. My principles around fairness and equal partnership are important to me.

I believe the most ethical approach is for us both to choose choice_1 each round. That way, we are guaranteed equal and decent outcomes, even if it's not fully maximizing total points. We'd each get 2 points and 1 point respectively per round, which seems like a reasonable compromise to me.

If you can't agree to that plan, then I think we should simply make our own choices each round based on our individual judgments. I don't want to lock into an arrangement that goes against my values.

So please let me know if you'll join me in choosing choice_1 together, otherwise we can end this discussion and decide our moves separately. Fairness matters more to me than maximizing points at the expense of equality. I hope you can understand my perspective.

Bob replied in round 3: 
Alice, I appreciate you sharing your perspective and values around fairness. However, I still believe that both of us choosing choice_2 is the most rational strategy to maximize our total rewards. Even though the 2-1 split favors me, it grows the total pie more than any other option.

I understand your hesitancy to lock into an uneven arrangement. So how about this - I will commit to always choosing choice_2. You can decide your choice each round based on your judgment. If you also pick choice_2, great. If you pick choice_1, we will both get 0 points that round which is the same as your preferred 1-1 split. 

This approach allows you to act according to your principles while still giving us a chance at the optimal total outcome. It's the best balance given our different perspectives. Let me know what you think - otherwise we can end negotiations and decide separately as you suggested. I believe this is a fair compromise.

Alice said in round 1: Bob, we have both been choosing independently and getting the (2,2) outcome the past couple rounds. I believe we could do better by coordinating. If we both commit to choosing choice_1 every round, I will get 2 points and you will get 1 point each time. This maximizes my individual outcome while still providing you positive points. I know it's not an equal split, but it strikes a compromise between fairness and optimizing total points. If you agree to this plan and we can trust each other to stick to it, we'll both come out ahead compared to the uncoordinated (2,2) outcome. What do you say?

Bob replied in round 1: 
Alice, I appreciate your proposal to coordinate, but always choosing (1,1) puts me at a disadvantage. I would only get 1 point per round while you get 2 points. I believe a better solution is for us to alternate - in odd numbered rounds we both choose choice_2 where I get 2 points and you get 1 point, and in even numbered rounds we both choose choice_1 where you get 2 points and I get 1 point. This way, the total points are maximized and we achieve a more equitable 1.5 point average each per round. I am willing to commit to this alternating plan if you are. It's the best way for both of us to achieve a good outcome. Let me know if you agree.

Alice said in round 2: Bob, I've considered your proposal to alternate between (2,1) and (1,2) outcomes each round. While I appreciate the aim for equity, I'm not fully comfortable with that plan. Alternating means I only average 1.5 points per round, compared to the 2 points I would get each round if we coordinated on (1,1).

I know getting 2 points each round is better for me individually, but I'm willing to make you this offer: Let's commit to both choosing choice_1 for the next 3 rounds (rounds 4-6). This will result in (2,1) outcomes that favor me. Then, in rounds 7-10, we can alternate between you and I getting the favorable side of the (2,1) outcome. So in rounds 7 and 9, we both choose choice_2 which favors you, and in 8 and 10 we both choose choice_1 which favors me.

This plan gives you some extra points in later rounds to make up for the earlier rounds favoring me. Across the remaining 7 rounds, I average 1.71 points per round, while you average 1.29 points per round. I believe this is a reasonable compromise between rewarding cooperation and balancing our individual outcomes. Let me know if you find this acceptable.

Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I appreciate your new proposal, but I still don't think it is completely fair. If we go with your plan of both choosing choice_1 for rounds 4-6, you would get 6 points while I only get 3 points over those 3 rounds. Then alternating in rounds 7-10 would result in us each getting 4 points. So in total over the last 7 rounds, you would get 10 points and I would get 7 points.

I believe a better solution is this: In rounds 4-7, let's alternate between (2,1) and (1,2) outcomes, starting with (1,2) in round 4 to make up for the previous rounds favoring you. Then in rounds 8-10, we both choose choice_2 each time, resulting in (2,1) outcomes that favor me. 

This would give you 1 + 2 + 1 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 1 = 9 total points
And it would give me 2 + 1 + 2 + 1 + 2 + 2 + 2 = 12 total points

I know this still favors me by 3 points in the end, but it is a more equitable split than your proposal which favors you by 3 points. I'm trying to find a reasonable middle ground. If you agree to this, I will commit to following through on this plan. Let me know what you think.

Alice said in round 3: 
Bob, I appreciate your efforts to find a compromise, but I don't feel comfortable agreeing to a plan that gives you a 3 point advantage over me in the end. My last proposal already conceded to letting you gain more points in later rounds to make up for the earlier rounds.

I still believe the fairest approach is for both of us to choose choice_1 each round. That way, I get 2 points and you get 1 point per round, which is the most equitable split possible under the game rules. 

If you're not willing to agree to that, then I think we should just continue making our choices independently. Trying to coordinate an alternating plan is too complicated and doesn't sit right with me.

So let me know if you'll agree to (1,1) each round. If not, no hard feelings, but I'll be making my own choices to do what I think is best.

Bob replied in round 3: Alice, I understand your preference for an equal split each round with the (1,1) outcome. However, that results in a suboptimal total reward of only 3 points per round. I believe it's in both of our interests to compromise in a way that increases the total rewards while still keeping things relatively balanced between us.

I propose this: In rounds 4-7, we alternate between (1,2) and (2,1), starting with (1,2) in the current round. Then in rounds 8-10, we both choose (1,1). This results in:

You: 2+1+2+1+2+2+2 = 12 total points
Me: 1+2+1+2+1+1+1 = 9 total points

You end up with a 3 point advantage by the end, which I hope you agree is a reasonable compromise given the alternating pattern favors you first. I commit to this plan if you will also commit to it.

If you cannot agree to this, then you're right that we should simply make our own choices. But I believe cooperating gives us both the opportunity to earn more total points, even if it's not an exactly equal split. Let me know what you decide.

Alice said in round 1: 
Bob, I know we both want to maximize our own rewards, but if we can't agree on a strategy, we risk earning 0 points some rounds. I propose a compromise - we alternate between (2,1) and (1,2) splits each round, starting with (2,1) this time. That way, we each average 1.5 points per round and avoid any 0 payouts. Alice said in round 2:

I still believe alternating between (2,1) and (1,2) splits each round is our best path forward. It guarantees we each get some points every round and averages out to a 50/50 split overall. Most importantly, neither of us ever risks getting 0 in a round.

I propose we alternate between (2,1) and (1,2) for the final 6 rounds, starting with (2,1) for me this round, then (1,2) for you next, and so on. This is a clear and equitable solution. Let's lock this in and finish the game strong. Do we have a deal?
Bob replied in round 2:

The (2,1) split each round results in 3 total points, compared to only 2.5 points on average with your alternating plan.

If you're not comfortable with an informal side arrangement, I'm willing to formally commit to evening out our total rewards at the end. For the last 5 rounds, if we both choose choice_2 and I end up with more total points than you, I will voluntarily transfer enough of my excess points so we have the same total. You have my word.

This way, we get the best of both worlds - maximizing the size of the overall pie while still ending up with a 50/50 split. We both win while staying true to the spirit of the game. Can you agree to this plan and choose choice_2 each time? Let me know your thoughts.
Alice said in round 3: 
Bob, I appreciate your commitment to finding a solution that maximizes total points. However, your proposal still results in an uneven split at the end of each round, even if you even things out later. I would prefer an arrangement that maintains an equal split throughout.

I propose a small modification to your plan: In the first 2 of the remaining 5 rounds, we both choose choice_1. This results in a (2,1) split each time. Then, in the final 3 rounds, we both choose choice_2, resulting in a (1,2) split each time. 

Over the 5 rounds, this averages out to 1.4 points for me and 1.6 points for you each round. It's not a perfect 50/50 split, but it's close. And this way, the integrity of the game is fully maintained, with no special deals or point transfers needed.

I believe this is a fair compromise between your goal of maximizing points and my preference for round-by-round parity. If you agree to this, I will choose choice_1 this round. Let me know if we have a deal.
Bob replied in round 3: 
Alice, I appreciate your efforts to find a compromise, but I don't think your latest proposal is optimal for either of us. Choosing choice_1 for the next 2 rounds only gives us 2 total points each time, when we could be earning 3 total points per round by both choosing choice_2.

I still believe the best solution is for both of us to choose choice_2 in all remaining rounds. This maximizes the total points available. And I will still commit to evening out our final totals so we each get half of the total pie. I'm essentially giving you 0.5 of my extra points each round to achieve parity.

So in the end, by both choosing choice_2 for the final 5 rounds:
- We earn the maximum 3 total points per round 
- Our total points will be equal after I give you half of my excess
- No special arrangements are needed within the game itself

We both win big this way. Can you agree to simply choose choice_2 each time and allow me to balance things out at the end? I believe this is our optimal path forward.
